Description: Body sherd (mended from three fragments) of Corinthian black-figured pottery open vessel, possibly a column-krater; interior: glazed black; exterior: from top, part of black band; black-figure decoration consisting of deer grazing to left (rump and hind legs missing; added red on neck and on belly); black area below.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The number 20 is written in pencil.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 122, pl. XVII, no. 346.1)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 230, no. 158)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.162) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4662 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
